name: Seattle Aquarium
description: Window on Washington Waters, tide pool touch tanks, marine mammals, Pacific Coral Reef, 9:30 a.m.-5 p.m. daily, 1483 Alaskan Way, Pier 59, Seattle.

name: Seattle Great Wheel
description: Gondola ride for all ages, 11 a.m.-10 p.m. Mondays-Thursdays, 11 a.m.-midnight Fridays, 10 a.m.-midnight Saturdays, 10 a.m.-10 p.m. Sundays; starting July, 10 a.m.-midnight Fridays-Saturdays, 10 a.m.-11 p.m. Sundays-Thursdays. Pier 57, 1301 Alaskan Way, Seattle.

name: Wings Over Washington
description: Pier 57, 1301 Alaskan Way, Seattle.

name: Argosy Cruises
description: Public sightseeing cruises including Harbor Cruise, Locks Cruise, Lake Washington Cruise, Historical Cruise on Lake Union, Wine Tasting and Tillicum Excursion, schedules vary, Pier 55 and 56, 1101 Alaskan Way, Seattle.

name: Discover Olympic Sculpture Park
description: One-hour walking tours exploring the park’s landscape design, native plants and art, 1 p.m. Saturdays-Sundays, PACCAR Pavilion; park open daily during daylight hours, Broad Street and Elliott Avenue, Seattle.

name: Space Needle Observation Deck
description: Observation Deck open with some sections closed during renovation; open 9 a.m.-10 p.m. Fridays-Saturdays, 10 a.m.-8 p.m. Sundays, 10 a.m.-9 p.m. Mondays-Thursdays, 305 Harrison St., Seattle.

name: “Marvel: Universe of Super Heroes”
description: Display of 300 pieces of art, costumes and props telling the Marvel story, including Spider-Man, Thor, Black Panther, Ms. Marvel, Hulk, Iron Man; other exhibits include “Nirvana: Taking It To The Masses,” “Star Trek: Exploring New Worlds,” “Infinite Worlds of Science Fiction,” “Fantasy: Worlds of Myth and Magic,” and “Scared to Death: The Thrill of Horror Film;” 10 a.m.-5 p.m. daily through May 24; 10 a.m.-7 p.m. May 25-Sept. 3, Museum of Pop Culture (MoPOP), 325 Fifth Ave. N., Seattle.

name: Pacific Science Center
details: $13.95-$23.95, ages 2 and younger free, additional charge for Laser and IMAX shows
description: Tropical Butterfly House, planetarium, BodyWorks, Science Playground, VR Microtheater, Laser Dome shows, IMAX theater; 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Mondays-Fridays, 10 a.m.-6 p.m. Saturdays-Sundays; 10 a.m.-6 p.m. daily June 18-Sept. 3, Pacific Science Center, 200 Second Ave. N., Seattle.

name: Chihuly Garden and Glass
description: Dale Chihuly’s glass art, garden with plants and art, 10 a.m.-8 p.m. Fridays-Saturdays, 10 a.m.-7 p.m. Sundays-Thursdays, Glasshouse occasionally closed for special events; 305 Harrison St., Seattle.

name: MOHAI
details: $15.95-$19.95, ages 14 and younger free; free for all First Thursdays
description: “Seattle on the Spot: The Photographs of Al Smith,” through June 17; permanent exhibits “True Northwest: The Seattle Journey,” Bezos Center for Innovation, “Maritime Seattle,” museum open 10 a.m.-5 p.m. daily, until 8 p.m. first Thursdays and every Thursday from July 5-Sept. 6, Museum of History & Industry (MOHAI), 860 Terry Ave. N., Seattle.

name: Seattle Ferry Service
description: Cruise on historic mini-ferry, 45-50 minute tour of the Lake Union floating homes, on hour 11 a.m.-4 p.m. Sundays, weather permitting, South Lake Union, 901 Fairview Ave. N., Seattle.

name: Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture
details: $7.50-$10, free for ages 4 and younger and UW students, faculty and staff
description: “Pacific Voices,” “Life and Times of Washington State,” “Washington’s First Dinosaur,” Ethnobotanic Garden, 10 a.m.-5 p.m. daily, until 8 p.m. first Thursdays; 17th Avenue Northeast and Northeast 45th Street, UW Campus, Seattle.

name: Woodland Park Zoo
description: Assam Rhino Reserve exhibit; baby gorilla Yola on view, 12:30 p.m.-closing daily; snow leopard cub and mother on view on even-numbered days of the month; Butterfly Garden tent structure, 500 free-flying butterflies, opening for the season May 25; open 9:30 a.m.-6 p.m. daily, closing 3 p.m. July 13 and 2 p.m. July 20 for special events.

name: Nordic Museum
description: Recently opened museum features core exhibition “Nordic Journeys,” 12,000 years of Nordic history and the story of Nordic immigration to the U.S. and Pacific Northwest; “Northern Exposure; Contemporary Nordic Arts Revealed,” 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Tuesdays through Sundays, until 8 p.m. Thursdays, 2655 N.W. Market St., Seattle.

name: Hiram M. Chittenden Locks
description: One of Seattle’s top tourist attractions; the Locks, Fish Ladder, gardens, open daylight hours daily; Visitors Center open 10 a.m.-6:30 p.m. daily; guided one-hour walking tours, 1 and 3 p.m. Mondays-Fridays, 11 a.m., 1 and 3 p.m. Saturdays-Sundays, no reservations needed; outdoor concerts on summer weekends; 3015 N.W. 54th St., Seattle.

name: Wing Luke Museum of the Asian Pacific American Experience
details: $30-$45; “Grilled Things and Chicken Wings” season food tours, 4:30-7 p.m. selected Fridays July-Sept., $30-$45; Wing Luke Museum of the Asian Pacific American Experience, 719 S. King St., Seattle; $10-$17
description: “Wham! Bam! Pow! Cartoons, Turbans & Confronting Hate” art exhibit to raise awareness about discrimination and challenge stereotypes, 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Tuesdays-Sundays, until 8 p.m. first Thursdays; guided Historic Hotel, Touch of Chinatown and other tours available daily; “The Rice Stuff” seasonal food tours, 4:30-7 p.m. select Fridays April-June,.

name: Museum of Flight
details: $14-$24, ages 4 and younger free; free admission 5-8 p.m. first Thursdays
description: The largest independent nonprofit air and space museum in the world, aircraft, spacecraft, artifacts, galleries, exhibits, Flight Simulators, 3D Movie Theater, Kids’ Flight Zone, Personal Courage Wing history of World War I and World War II, The William E. Boeing Red Barn, 10 a.m.-5 p.m. daily, 9404 E. Marginal Way S., Seattle.

name: Northwest Railway Museum Train Rides
description: Two-hour round-trip excursions on historic train on scenic rides through the Cascade Foothills to the top of Snoqualmie Falls, Victorian-era depot, 11 a.m. Saturdays-Sundays, Northwest Railway Museum, 38625 S.E. King St., Snoqualmie.

name: CityPass
description: For visitors or a staycation, valid for nine consecutive days at five attractions, the Space Needle; Seattle Aquarium; Argosy Cruises Harbor Tour; Museum of Pop Culture (MoPOP) or Woodland Park Zoo; Chihuly Garden and Glass or Pacific Science Center,.

name: Mount Rainier National Park
details: $25/per vehicle for seven days or $10/person walk up or bicycle
description: National Park Inn, Longmire Museum Visitor Center and Henry M. Jackson Memorial Visitor Center at Paradise open year-around, hours vary; Paradise Inn lodging, dining, gift shop opens for the season May 18; Ohanapecosh Visitor Center opens late June, Sunrise Visitor Center opens in July; 39000 State Route 706 E, Ashford.

name: Mounger Pool
description: Outdoor Big Pool with corkscrew slide, shallow Little Pool; swim lessons, open swims, themed events, hours vary daily, 2535 32nd Ave. W., Seattle.

name: Enchanted Village and Wild Waves Water Park
description: Fun park rides only, 10:30 a.m.-6 p.m. May 12-13, 19-20; fun park and water park, 10:30 a.m.-6 p.m. May 26-28, 9 a.m.-4 p.m. June 1, 10:30 a.m.-6 p.m. June 2-3, 9 a.m.-4 p.m. June 6-8, 10:30 a.m.-6 p.m. June 9-10, 9 a.m.-4 p.m. June 11-15; 10:30 a.m.-7 p.m. June 16-25, 27-28; 10:30 a.m. 8 p.m. June 29 through Aug. 31; 10:30 a.m.-7 p.m. Sept. 1-3; Wild Waves & Enchanted Village, 36201 Enchanted Parkway S., Federal Way.

name: Remlinger Farms Country Fair Fun Park
description: Thru Sept. 3 Farm animals, entertainment, rides and attractions for children, 10:30 a.m.-4:30 p.m. Saturdays-Sundays through June 20, 10:30 a.m.-4:30 p.m. daily June 21-Sept. 3, Remlinger Farms, 32610 N.E. 32nd St., Carnation.

name: Point Defiance Zoo and Aquarium
description: Budgie Buddies opening weekend, feed colorful Australian birds, May 12-13, open 10:30 a.m.-1 p.m. and 2-5 p.m. weekends, 10:30 a.m.-2 p.m. weekdays; Wild Wonders Shows daily; World Ocean Weekend activities June 2-3; Half-Price Dads Day and activities June 17; World Tiger Day activities, July 28; open 9:30 a.m.-5 p.m. daily through June 29; 9:30 a.m.-6 p.m. daily June 30-Sept. 3, Point Defiance Zoo & Aquarium, 5400 N. Pearl St., Tacoma.

name: Syttende Mai
description: Norway Constitution Day celebration; children’s activities, Fjord horses, 10 a.m.-5 p.m., Nordic Heritage Museum, 2655 N.W. Market St.; musical entertainment, 2-6 p.m., Bergen Place Park, 22nd Avenue Northwest and Northwest Market Street; open house heritage displays, entertainment, noon-5 p.m., Leif Erikson Hall, 2245 N.W. 57th St., Seattle; 17th of May Ballard Parade, 6 p.m. on 24th Avenue Northwest from Northwest 62nd Street to Northwest Market Street, Seattle.

name: A Glimpse of China Chinese Culture & Arts Festival
description: Creative traditions, performances and food, Seattle Center Armory, Seattle.

name: West Seattle Bee Festival
description: Kids & Pets Parade, 11 a.m.; art and science activities, music, food, Vendor Fair, Woodland Park Zoo live animal program, 10 a.m.-3 p.m., High Point Commons Park, 6400 Sylvan Way S.W., Seattle.

name: Petapalooza
description: Dog Trot 3K/5K Fun Run, 9:30 a.m.; animal-related entertainment stage, flydog and agility demos, pony rides, agility area, vendors, pet adoptions and services, activities for pets and humans, 10 a.m.-5 p.m., Game Farm Park, 3030 R St. S.E., Auburn.

name: Paine Field Aviation Day
details: $25-$45, Paine Field, 3407 109th St. S.W., Everett; $15, ages 9 and younger free; $35/family pass, two adults and children
description: Flying Heritage & Combat Armor Museum and Historic Flight Foundation exhibits, food vendors, flight schools, flying demonstrations, 10 a.m.-5 p.m.; 5K/10K run/walk, 8:30 a.m.,.

name: Armed Forces Day Parade, Bremerton
description: The largest Armed Forces Day Parade in the nation, in its 71st year; all branches of the military, police and firefighters, youth organizations, dignitaries, commercial businesses, car clubs; 10 a.m., downtown Bremerton.

name: U District Street Fair
description: Hundreds of craft and food vendors, music, beer garden, kids’ activities, 10 a.m.-7 p.m. May 19, 10 a.m.-6 p.m. May 20, University Way Northeast from Campus Parkway to North 50th Street, Seattle.

name: Beat The Bridge
description: 8K run with wheelchair division with challenge to cross the University Bridge before it’s raised; 3 mile/1 mile walk/fun run through UW campus; proceeds benefit JDRF (Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation), 8 a.m. Husky Stadium, 3800 Montlake Blvd., Seattle.

name: Girls On The Run 5K
description: Run to benefit Girls on the Run of Puget Sound, 9:30 a.m. Renton Stadium, 405 N. Logan Ave., Renton.

name: Touch-A-Truck
description: Children explore working trucks and meet operators; kids’ activities, food trucks, 10 a.m.-1 p.m., quiet hour 9-10 a.m., Magnuson Park, 7400 Sand Point Way N.E., Seattle.

name: Mushroom Maynia
description: Safe cultivation, hunting and harvesting methods, art and crafts, nature walks, 10 a.m.-4 p.m., Center for Urban Horticulture, 3501 N.E. 41st St., Seattle.

name: Intercultural Festival
description: International food, entertainment, folk dancing, arts and crafts, children’s games, 11 a.m.-5 p.m., St. Thomas More Catholic Church, 6511 176th St. S.W., Lynnwood.

name: Tour of Boats, Classic Cars, Marine Swap Meet
description: Boat tours, wear soft soled shoes; food trucks; benefits local charities, noon-4 p.m., Tacoma Yacht Club, 5401 N. Waterfront Drive, Tacoma.

name: Bicycle Sunday
description: , 27 Lake Washington Boulevard closed to motorized vehicles, open to bike, stroll or jog, 10 a.m.-6 p.m. and 27, between Seward Park and Mount Baker Park beach, Seattle; opening day celebration 10 a.m.-2 p.m. , Seward Park.

name: Northwest Folklife Festival
description: Multicultural music and dance performances at indoor and outdoor venues around Seattle Center, Seattle Center, Seattle; donations requested.

name: Tankfest NW
details: $15-$25, free for active military, veterans and ages 5 and younger
description: Vintage tanks and artillery, military vehicle demonstrations, kids’ activities, 9 a.m.-4 p.m., Flying Heritage & Combat Armor Museum, 3407 109th St. S.W., Paine Field, Everett.

name: Seagull Calling Contest
description: Farmers market, car show, 9 a.m.-3 p.m.; wings cook-off and sale, 9 a.m.-noon; seagull calling contest, 1 p.m., Port Orchard Marina, Port Orchard.

name: Kitsap Harbor Festival
description: Pirates, craft and food vendors, kids’ activities, entertainment, beer garden, 10 a.m.-6 p.m. May 26, 10 a.m.-5 p.m. May 27, Bremerton Marina and Port Orchard Marina, 707.

name: East Green Lake, Madrona beaches
description: Life guards on duty, weather permitting, 2-7 p.m. weekdays through June 22; noon-7 p.m. weekdays June 23-Aug. 26, 11 a.m.-7 p.m. Saturdays-Sundays through Aug. 26, Madrona Beach, 853 Lake Washington Blvd., and East Green Lake, East Green Lake Beach, 7201 E. Green Lake Drive N., Seattle.

name: Colman Pool
description: Heated, saltwater Olympic size pool, Giant Tube Slide; open swims, swimming lessons, special events, Colman Pool, Lincoln Park, 8603 Fauntleroy Way S.W., Seattle; hours and fees vary.

name: Renton History Museum
description: “On the Battlefront and the Homefront: Rentonites in the Great War” exhibit on local residents who served on the battlefront and homefront during World War I, ; “I’m Going Through: Black Miners Arrive in King County” exhibit in honor of Renton’s Juneteenth celebration, tracing the arrival of African American miners and their families in King County in the 1880s and 1890s, June 1-Aug. 31; 10 a.m.-4 p.m. Tuesdays-Saturdays, Renton History Museum, 235 Mill Ave. S., Renton.

name: Beach Naturalist Program
description: Explore the beach at low tide with trained volunteers; 10 a.m.-12:30 p.m. May 29; 10:30 a.m.-1 p.m. May 30; 11:15 a.m.-1:45 p.m. May 31; 1-3 p.m. June 2; 9:30 a.m.-12:30 p.m. June 13; 9:30 a.m.-1 p.m. June 14; 10 a.m.-2 p.m. June 15; 11 a.m.-3 p.m. June 16; noon-3:30 p.m. June 17; 11 a.m.-1:30 p.m. June 29; 11:45 a.m.-1:45 p.m. June 30; 9-11:30 a.m. July 11; 9 a.m.-12:30 p.m. July 12; 9:30 a.m.-1:30 p.m. July 13; 10:30 a.m.-2:30 p.m. July 14; 11:15 a.m.-2:45 p.m. July 15; 11 a.m.-1 p.m. July 28; 9-11 a.m. Aug. 9; 9 a.m.-noon Aug. 10; 10 a.m.-1 p.m. Aug. 11; 10:30 a.m.-1:30 p.m. Aug. 12, Carkeek Park, Golden Gardens, South Alki, Lincoln Park, Carkeek Park, Seattle; Richmond Beach, Shoreline; Seahurst Park, Burien; Saltwater State Park, Des Moines.

name: Bellevue Jazz & Blues Festival
description: Regional jazz and blues musicians, middle and high school jazz performances throughout downtown Bellevue, ; locations and costs vary.
